title: ion-select
body: Selects are form controls to select an option, or options, from a set of options, similar to a native
element. When a user taps the select, a dialog appears with all of the options in a large, easy to select list.
A select should be used with child
elements. If the child option is not given a
attribute then its text will be used as the value.
, the selected option will be chosen based on that value.
to open up the overlay of options in an alert. The interface can be changed to use
property. Read on to the other sections for the limitations of the different interfaces.

By default, the select allows the user to select only one option. The alert interface presents users with a radio button styled list of options. The action sheet interface can only be used with a single value select. The select component's value receives the value of the selected option's value.

attribute to select, users are able to select multiple options. When multiple options can be selected, the alert overlay presents users with a checkbox styled list of options. The select component's value receives an array of all of the selected option values.
interfaces will not work with multiple selection.

When using objects for select values, it is possible for the identities of these objects to change if they are coming from a server or database, while the selected value's identity remains the same. For example, this can occur when an existing record with the desired object value is loaded into the select, but the newly retrieved select options now have different identities. This will result in the select appearing to have no value at all, even though the original selection in still intact.
By default, the select uses object equality (
) to determine if an option is selected. This can be overridden by providing a property name or a function to the
. Each button's text can be customized using the
button, clicking on any of the options will automatically close the overlay and select that value. The
button, clicking on the backdrop will close the overlay.
Since select uses the alert, action sheet and popover interfaces, options can be passed to these components through the
property. This can be used to pass a custom header, subheader, css class, and more.
for the properties that each interface accepts.

props.name: cancelText
props.docs: The text to display on the cancel button.

props.name: compareWith
props.type: ((currentValue: any, compareValue: any) => boolean) | null | string | undefined
props.docs: A property name or function used to compare object values

props.name: disabled
props.docs: If true, the user cannot interact with the select.

props.name: interface
props.docs: The interface the select should use: action-sheet, popover or alert.

props.name: interfaceOptions
props.docs:
Any additional options that the alert, action-sheet or popover interface can take. See the ion-alert docs, the ion-action-sheet docs and the ion-popover docs for the create options for each interface.

Note: interfaceOptions will not override inputs or buttons with the alert interface.

props.name: mode
props.docs: The mode determines which platform styles to use.

props.name: multiple
props.docs: If true, the select can accept multiple values.

props.name: name
props.docs: The name of the control, which is submitted with the form data.

props.name: okText
props.docs: The text to display on the ok button.

props.name: placeholder
props.docs: The text to display when the select is empty.

props.name: selectedText
props.docs: The text to display instead of the selected option's value.

methods.name: open
methods.docs: Open the select overlay. The overlay is either an alert, action sheet, or popover, depending on the interface property on the ion-select.

docsTags.name: param
docsTags.text: event The user interface event that called the open.

docs: Selects are form controls to select an option, or options, from a set of options, similar to a native `

` element. When a user taps the select, a dialog appears with all of the options in a large, easy to select list.

A select should be used with child `` elements. If the child option is not given a `value` attribute then its text will be used as the value.

If `value` is set on the ``, the selected option will be chosen based on that value.

docsTags.text: {"ios" | "md"} mode - The mode determines which platform styles to use.
docsTags.name: virtualProp

docsTags.text: placeholder - The text displayed in the select when there is no value.
docsTags.name: part

docsTags.text: text - The displayed value of the select.
docsTags.name: part

events.docs: Emitted when the select loses focus.
Emitted when the selection is cancelled.
Emitted when the value has changed.
Emitted when the select has focus.

styles.name: --padding-end
styles.docs: Right padding if direction is left-to-right, and left padding if direction is right-to-left of the select

styles.name: --padding-start
styles.docs: Left padding if direction is left-to-right, and right padding if direction is right-to-left of the select

styles.name: --placeholder-color
styles.docs: Color of the select placeholder text

styles.name: --placeholder-opacity
styles.docs: Opacity of the select placeholder text
